title: 115_hr1638
content: The Act may be cited as the "Iranian Leadership Asset Transparency Act". The Congress finds that Iran has high levels of corruption, with the IRGC involved in the economy. Senior leaders have gained wealth through their positions, and sanctions relief has removed corrupt entities from the US sanctions list. The Treasury designated Iran's financial sector as a jurisdiction in 2011. The USA PATRIOT Act has identified the entire Iranian financial sector, including Iran's Central Bank and private banks, as posing money laundering risks. Iran is listed by the FATF as a non-cooperative country in the fight against terror finance and money laundering, along with North Korea. Iran is ranked 130th out of 168 countries in the Transparency International index of public corruption. The State Department has identified Iran as a major money-laundering country and a state sponsor of terrorism, supporting terrorist groups worldwide through the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps-Qods Force. Iran, Hizballah, and other Shia militia groups support the Asad regime in Syria, prolonging the civil war and worsening the human rights crisis. The Iranian Government's tolerance of corruption and nepotism hinders foreign and domestic investment, with the IRGC and bonyads controlling a significant portion of Iran's economy. The IRGC and bonyads control major economic sectors in Iran, providing funds for terrorist organizations like Hezbollah and Hamas, further disadvantaging the average Iranian. SEC. 3. REPORT REQUIREMENT RELATING TO ASSETS OF IRANIAN LEADERS AND CERTAIN SENIOR POLITICAL FIGURES. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit a report to congressional committees within 270 days of the Act's enactment, and annually thereafter for two years, detailing funds held by individuals at US and foreign financial institutions to prevent financing of terrorism and money laundering. The Secretary of the Treasury must report on individuals' equity stakes in sanctioned entities, how funds were acquired and used, new evasion techniques, and recommendations to combat illicit financial activities. Additionally, recommendations on revising economic sanctions against Iran to prevent misuse of funds by these individuals. The curr_chunk discusses the need for natural persons to contribute to the development of ballistic missile technology by Iran and human rights abuses. It also includes an assessment of the impact and effectiveness of US economic sanctions programs against Iran, along with recommendations for improving the Department of the Treasury's ability to enforce additional sanctions if ordered by the President. The curr_chunk lists key individuals in Iran, including the Supreme Leader, President, and various military commanders, who are subject to sanctions under the Emergency Economic Powers Act. The curr_chunk lists key individuals in Iran subject to sanctions under the Emergency Economic Powers Act, including the head of the IRGC Joint Staff, Commander of the IRGC Intelligence, head of the IRGC Imam Hussein University, Supreme Leader's Representative at the IRGC, CEO and Chairman of the IRGC Cooperative Foundation, Commander of the Khatam-al-Anbia Construction Head Quarter, CEO of the Basij Cooperative Foundation, head of the Political Bureau of the IRGC, and head of the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran. The report required shall be submitted in unclassified form with a possible classified annex. The unclassified portion of the report on key individuals in Iran subject to sanctions will be made public in multiple languages and easily downloadable formats on the Department of the Treasury's website. The Secretary of the Treasury can use various credible sources of information, including publications, databases, and information from government agencies or nongovernmental organizations. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "funds" includes cash, equity, intangible assets, and other assets determined by the Secretary. Congress believes the Secretary of the Treasury should gather information from sources that collect official records or provide analysis tools for law enforcement to gain new insights into financial relationships. (Passed the House of Representatives December 13, 2017)
